title: Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley
text:
Allen Algernon Bathurst, Lord Apsley, <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a>, <a href="Military%20Cross">MC</a>, <a href="Territorial%20Decoration">TD</a>, <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">DL</a> (3 August 1895 – 17 December 1942) was a <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer and <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a> politician.
Early life.
Apsley was the eldest son of <a href="Seymour%20Bathurst%2C%207th%20Earl%20Bathurst">Seymour Bathurst, 7th Earl Bathurst</a> and his wife <a href="Lilias%20Margaret%20Frances%2C%20Countess%20Bathurst">Lilias Margaret Frances</a> "née" Borthwick, daughter of <a href="Algernon%20Borthwick%2C%201st%20Baron%20Glenesk">Algernon Borthwick, 1st Baron Glenesk</a>. He was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton</a> and <a href="Christ%20Church%2C%20Oxford">Christ Church, Oxford</a>, graduating BA hons.
Military career.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, he served overseas with the <a href="Royal%20Gloucestershire%20Hussars">Royal Gloucestershire Hussars</a>. He was promoted to temporary lieutenant in April 1916, acting <a href="captain%20%28OF-2%29">captain</a> in June 1917, receiving a substantive promotion to lieutenant from the same date, and to substantive captain in 1918. He was awarded the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> (MC) and <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) for his actions in Egypt:
Political and business career.
He was elected as <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for <a href="Southampton%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Southampton</a> in 1922, holding the seat until 1929. He then stood for <a href="Bristol%20Central%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Bristol Central</a> in 1931, and held the seat until his death in 1942. In 1923 he was appointed a <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> for the "<a href="Gloucestershire">County of Gloucester</a>, and of the <a href="Gloucester">City and County of the City of Gloucester</a>, and the <a href="Bristol">City and County of the City of Bristol</a>."
During this time, he was <a href="Parliamentary%20Private%20Secretary">Parliamentary Private Secretary</a> to: the <a href="Under-Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20the%20Overseas%20Trade%20Department">Under-Secretary of State for the Overseas Trade Department</a> 1922–24, the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Transport">Minister of Transport</a> 1925-29 and the <a href="Minister%20for%20Co-ordination%20Defence">Minister for Co-ordination Defence</a> 1936. He had also been President of the <a href="UK%20Pilot%27s%20Association">UK Pilot's Association</a> in 1925 and sometime chairman of <a href="Western%20Airways">Western Airways</a>, <a href="Western%20Air%20Transport%20Company">Western Air Transport Company</a> and a director of <a href="Morning%20Post">Morning Post</a>. Lord and Lady Apsley published a book called "The Amateur Settlers" in 1929 recounting their escapades and adventures travelling through in the Northern Territory of Australia. They had many encounters, including with local aborigines, in which detailed descriptions reveal their social attitudes and behaviour.
He remained a member of the <a href="Territorial%20Army%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Territorial Army</a> between the wars, and was awarded the <a href="Territorial%20Decoration">Territorial Decoration</a> (TD) in 1929, promoted to <a href="brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> in 1930, and promoted to substantive major in 1938. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, he served overseas again, with the <a href="Arab%20Legion">Arab Legion</a> (1941–42).
Marriage.
On 27 February 1924, Lord Apsley had married <a href="Viola%20Bathurst%2C%20Lady%20Apsley">Viola Meeking</a> (who succeeded him as MP for Bristol Central) and they had two sons: <a href="Henry%20Bathurst%2C%208th%20Earl%20Bathurst">Henry Allen John</a> (1927–2011) and George Bertram (1929–2010). As Lord Apsley predeceased his father, the latter's earldom later passed to Lord Apsley's eldest son, Henry.
Death.
Lord Apsley was a passenger on a <a href="Handley%20Page%20Halifax">Handley Page Halifax</a> of <a href="No.%20138%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 138 Squadron RAF</a> when it crashed on take-off from Malta, killing all on board. Apsley was buried with the other victims at <a href="Kalkara%20Naval%20Cemetery">Kalkara Naval Cemetery</a> in <a href="Kalkara">Kalkara</a>.
